questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to your clinic for her postpartum checkup. She mentions that she has been exclusively breastfeeding her newborn and is concerned about meeting her own nutritional needs in order to ensure the best for her baby. She asks you about specific nutrient supplementation she might need during this period of lactation. Compared to her pregnancy, which nutrient would you recommend she should pay particular attention to increasing? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Vitamin A

 

  • The requirement for Vitamin A increases during lactation more than during pregnancy.
  • Vitamin A is essential for ensuring the quality of breast milk, which is the sole source of nutrition for a newborn.
  • It plays a critical role in the development of the baby’s immune system and visual function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to the latest Nutritional Guidelines,

 

  • Requirement in Pregnancy > Lactation → Proteins; Zinc; Folic Acid; Iron
  • Requirement in Lactation > Pregnancy → Vitamin A; Iodine; Vitamin C; Carbohydrates, Calcium
  • Requirement in Pregnancy = Lactation → Vitamin D; Calcium

questions.text: Which of these is the most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insulinoma

 

The most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas is C) Insulinoma. These tumors are derived from the beta cells of the pancreas and are often associated with excessive insulin production, leading to hypoglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrinoma:

  • Gastrinoma is a type of neuroendocrine tumor that primarily arises in the pancreas or duodenum.
  • It is associated with the overproduction of gastrin, which leads to excessive stomach acid production.
  • This condition can result in peptic ulcers, acid reflux, and gastrin-related symptoms (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome).
  • Gastrinomas are often associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1).

 

Option B. Somatostatinoma:

  • Somatostatinoma is a rare neuroendocrine tumor that can occur in various parts of the gastrointestinal tract, including the pancreas.
  • These tumors produce excessive amounts of somatostatin, a hormone that inhibits the release of other hormones.
  • Symptoms may include diabetes mellitus, diarrhea, and gallstones.
  • Diagnosis and management often involve surgical removal and somatostatin analog medications.

 

Option D. VIPoma:

  • VIPoma, also known as Verner-Morrison syndrome, is a rare neuroendocrine tumor typically found in the pancreas.
  • It produces excessive amounts of vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP), leading to severe diarrhea and electrolyte imbalances.
  • Patients with VIPoma often experience "WDHA syndrome" (Watery Diarrhea, Hypokalemia, Achlorhydria).
  • Treatment involves addressing fluid and electrolyte imbalances and managing the tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Insulinoma is the most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas, arising from beta cells and frequently causing hypoglycemia due to excessive insulin production.

choices.text: Fundus and body of Gall bladder

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an anterior relation of the third part of the duodenum? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Fundus and body of Gall bladder

 

Explanation:

 

The fundus and body of the gallbladder are not typically considered anterior relations of the third part of the duodenum. The gallbladder is situated more to the right and superior to the duodenum, so it is not directly in front of it.

 

Note - The junction of the first and second parts of the duodenum lies posterior to the neck of the gallbladder. The anterior relations of the third segment of the duodenum comprise the Superior mesenteric vessels, the Root of the mesentery, and Loops of the jejunum

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Superior mesenteric vessels: The superior mesenteric vessels, which include the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) and superior mesenteric vein (SMV), are anterior relations of the third part of the duodenum. The SMA runs just posterior to the third part of the duodenum, and the SMV is typically located to the right of the SMA and also in front of the duodenum.

 

Option B) Loops of jejunum:  Loops of the jejunum, which are part of the small intestine, can lie anterior to the third part of the duodenum. The small intestine, including the jejunum, is positioned in the abdominal cavity, and its loops can be found in close proximity to the duodenum.

 

Option C) Root of mesentery: The root of the mesentery is an extension of the peritoneum that connects the small intestine (including the jejunum and ileum) to the posterior abdominal wall. It passes in front of the third part of the duodenum as it continues to the jejunum and ileum. Therefore, it is an anterior relation of the third part of the duodenum.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following conditions would have the highest levels of ACTH and cortisol? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cushing’s disease

 

Among the given conditions, the levels of ACTH and cortisol will be highest in Cushing's disease.

 

Cushing disease occurs when a pituitary adenoma, a noncancerous (benign) tumor on the pea-size pituitary gland, secretes too much adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH).

 

Normally, ACTH levels are higher in the early morning but not as high as in Cushing's disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Early morning: Incorrect because, although cortisol levels are typically highest in the early morning, they do not reach the levels observed in pathological conditions like Cushing's disease. This diurnal variation is normal, with peak levels upon waking and declining throughout the day.

 

Option B. Normal individuals with dexamethasone administration: Incorrect because dexamethasone is a synthetic steroid that acts similarly to cortisol. In normal individuals, administration of dexamethasone typically suppresses ACTH and cortisol production through negative feedback mechanisms.

 

Option C. Addison's disease: Incorrect because Addison's disease is characterized by adrenal insufficiency, where the adrenal glands produce insufficient cortisol and often underproduce aldosterone. While ACTH levels might be elevated due to lack of feedback inhibition, cortisol levels are low, not high.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cushing's disease specifically leads to elevated levels of both ACTH and cortisol due to an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma, distinguishing it from other conditions listed that involve different regulatory mechanisms of these hormones.

choices.text: Pain and temperature loss in the same side
Pain and temperature loss in the opposite side
Loss of tactile and proprioception on the same side
Loss of tactile and proprioception on the opposite side

questions.text: Lesion in the medial lemniscus at the level of pons causes which of the following?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Loss of tactile and proprioception on the opposite side

 

Explanation

 

Lesion in the medial lemniscus at the level of pons causes loss of tactile and proprioception on the opposite side.

 

The first order neurons carry sensory information regarding touch, proprioception or vibration from the peripheral nerves to the medulla oblongata by two different pathways 

 

  • Signals from the upper limb (T6 and above) – travel in the fasciculus cuneatus (the lateral part of the dorsal column). They then synapse in the nucleus cuneatus of the medulla oblongata.
  • Signals from the lower limb (below T6) – travel in the fasciculus gracilis (the medial part of the dorsal column). They then synapse in the nucleus gracilis of the medulla oblongata.

 

The second order neuron begin in the cuneate nucleus or gracilis. The fibres receive the information from the preceding neuron, and delivers it to the third order neuron in the thalamus. Within the medulla oblongata, these fibres decussate (cross to the other side of the CNS). They then travel in the contralateral medial lemniscus to reach the thalamus.

 

Lastly, the third order neuron transmit the sensory signals from the thalamus to the ipsilateral primary sensory cortex of the brain. They ascend from the ventral posterolateral nucleus of the thalamus, travel through the internal capsule and terminate at the sensory cortex.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pain and temperature loss in the same side: Incorrect, as the medial lemniscus does not primarily carry pain and temperature sensations; these are transmitted by the spinothalamic tract.

 

Option B. Pain and temperature loss in the opposite side: Incorrect for the same reason as above.

 

Option C. Loss of tactile and proprioception on the same side: Incorrect because the crossing of fibers in the medulla means that a lesion in the medial lemniscus at the pons affects the opposite side of the body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A lesion in the medial lemniscus at the level of the pons causes loss of tactile sense and proprioception on the opposite side of the body due to the decussation (crossing over) of second-order neurons in the medulla, which then ascend contralaterally in the medial lemniscus to the brain.

questions.text: A patient presented with clinical features of ataxia and incoordination. This is due to thrombosis of which artery? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Superior cerebellar

 

  • Thrombosis of the superior cerebellar artery causes cerebellar lesion which presents with ataxia and incoordination.
  • The superior cerebellar artery (SCA) is a branch of the basilar artery and supplies the superior surface of the cerebellum, the roof nuclei, and parts of the midbrain.
  • When there is a thrombosis (formation of a blood clot) in the SCA, the blood supply to these areas is disrupted, which can cause various neurological symptoms such as ataxia, incoordination, and dizziness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior cerebral artery (PCA): It supplies blood to the occipital lobe, parts of the temporal lobe, and the inferomedial portion of the thalamus.

 

  • Thrombosis of the PCA can lead to:
    • Contralateral homonymous hemianopia (loss of half of the field of vision in both eyes)
    • Memory impairment (if it affects the hippocampus)
    • Alexia without agraphia (an inability to read without an inability to write) if the dominant hemisphere is involved.

 

Option B. Middle cerebral artery (MCA): It supplies blood to the majority of the outer convex brain surface, including the frontal, parietal, and superior temporal lobes.

 

  • Thrombosis of the MCA can lead to:
    • Contralateral hemiparesis and sensory loss (mainly of the face and upper limb)
    • If the dominant hemisphere (typically the left in right-handed individuals) is affected, expressive aphasia can occur.
    • If the non-dominant hemisphere is involved, spatial neglect might be observed.

 

Option C. Internal carotid artery (ICA): It does not give off any significant branches in its cervical or petrous portions. Its terminal branches in the brain are the MCA and ACA (anterior cerebral artery). Thrombosis of the ICA can compromise blood flow to both the ACA and MCA territories, leading to a combination of the symptoms associated with obstruction of those arteries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blood supply of cerebellum:

 

  • Superior cerebellar artery
  • Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • Anterior inferior cerebellar artery

 

Common symptoms of cerebellar lesions:

questions.text:
A pregnant mother was on SSRIs. The risk of which of the following is increased in the newborn? (INICET Nov 2022)

  1. Low APGAR score.
  2. ADHD.
  3. Persistent pulmonary hypertension.
  4. Delayed developmental milestones.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a, b, c, d

 

Explanation:

 

a. Low APGAR score: SSRIs in late pregnancy can lead to neonatal adaptation syndrome, impacting the APGAR score.

 

b. ADHD: Some research suggests a potential link between prenatal SSRI exposure and ADHD.

 

c. Persistent pulmonary hypertension: Late-pregnancy SSRI exposure is associated with this risk.

 

d. Delayed developmental milestones: There's some evidence linking SSRIs to delayed milestones, though it's less consistent.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

SSRIs during pregnancy are linked to multiple neonatal risks. They may increase the risk of cardiac birth defects, decreased gestational age, spontaneous abortion, decreased birth weight, suboptimal fetal growth, low APGAR scores, autism spectrum disorders, ADHD and persistent pulmonary hypertension (SSRIs and SNRIs).

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 687-688

questions.text: A patient is found on a railway track with hot dry skin, raised temperature, dilated pupils, slurred speech, and a staggering gait. Which of the following is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dhatura poisoning

 

The patient presents with several characteristic signs and symptoms: hot dry skin, raised temperature (hyperthermia), dilated pupils (mydriasis), slurred speech, and staggering gait. These symptoms are indicative of anticholinergic poisoning, and specifically point towards Dhatura poisoning.

 

Dhatura (Datura) is a plant that contains tropane alkaloids, such as atropine, scopolamine, and hyoscyamine, which have strong anticholinergic effects.

 

These effects include: (Mnemonic DHATURA)

 

  • Dryness of skin and mucous membranes (due to inhibition of sweat and salivary glands).
  • Hyperthermia (elevated body temperature) because of decreased sweating.
  • Mydriasis (Dilated pupils), leading to photophobia and blurred vision.
  • Agitation
  • Tachycardia.
  • Urinary Retention and loss of accommodation (difficulty focusing).
  • Accommodation loss – Blurred Vision

 

Slurred speech and staggering gait can also be observed due to central nervous system effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Alcohol intoxication: While slurred speech and a staggering gait are common in alcohol intoxication, alcohol typically causes hypothermia (lowered body temperature), not hyperthermia. Also, alcohol intoxication generally does not cause hot, dry skin or dilated pupils.

 

Option C. Opioid overdose: This usually presents with pinpoint pupils (miosis), respiratory depression, and unconsciousness, not dilated pupils, hyperthermia, or dry skin.

 

Option D. Cocaine poisoning: Cocaine can cause hyperthermia and dilated pupils, but it typically results in increased activity and agitation rather than the slurred speech and staggering gait associated with Dhatura poisoning. Additionally, the dry skin is more characteristic of anticholinergic toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dhatura poisoning is characterized by anticholinergic symptoms such as hot dry skin, hyperthermia, dilated pupils, slurred speech, and a staggering gait, distinguishing it from other causes of altered mental status.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female with a history of chronic stable angina is seen in the outpatient department. She is already taking aspirin and statins, but continues to experience occasional chest pain during exertion. Which of the following would be the most appropriate choice for prophylactic treatment of her angina? (Fmge July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oral nitroglycerine

 

Oral nitroglycerine is the most appropriate choice for the prophylactic treatment of chronic stable angina in this patient. Long-acting nitrate preparations, like oral nitroglycerine, are used to prevent angina episodes rather than for immediate relief.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sublingual nitroglycerine: This is used for rapid relief during an acute angina attack, not as a prophylactic treatment.

 

Option B. Intravenous nitroglycerine: This form is typically used in acute care settings, such as for unstable angina or during a myocardial infarction, not for routine prophylaxis.

 

Option D. Intratracheal nitroglycerine: This is not a recognized route of administration for nitroglycerine in the treatment of angina.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oral nitroglycerine, a long-acting nitrate preparation, is the most appropriate choice for the prophylactic treatment of chronic stable angina to prevent angina episodes during exertion.

choices.text: Incidence reduces and prevalence remains the same
Incidence remains the same and prevalence increases

questions.text: A team of oncologists is implementing a new treatment strategy for metastatic melanoma that significantly improves overall survival rates for patients. How would you categorize the change in incidence and prevalence of metastatic melanoma in the population treated at this center? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Incidence remains the same and prevalence increases

 

  • The given scenario shows that there is a new treatment which can extend overall survival but cannot cure a particular disease.
  • So, old cases will live longer and thus, there will be increase in prevalence. Incidence will not get affected due to this.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incidence increases and prevalence reduces: Incorrect as the new treatment does not affect the number of new cases.

 

Option B. Incidence reduces and prevalence remains the same: Incorrect because the incidence is unaffected by treatment, and the prevalence would increase due to longer survival.

 

Option D. Incidence reduces and prevalence increases: Incorrect because the incidence remains the same.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PREVALENCE

 

  • Total current (Old + New) cases in a given population over.
  • Prevalence = Incidence × Mean duration of disease [P = I × d]
  • Prevalence describes the balance between incidence, mortality and recovery

 

INCIDENCE

 

  • Number of new cases occurring in a defined population over a specified period of time.

 

Note - A treatment that extends the lives of patients with a chronic condition will increase prevalence, even if incidence remains stable.

choices.text: Secure airway, ICD placement, and IV fluids
Start IV fluids, give atropine and send for chest x-ray
Administer IV Dextrose and send for CT
Evaluate for head injury and perform surgery

questions.text: A patient with a history of chest trauma with breathlessness on examination is found to have systolic BP of 90 mmHg, SpO2 of 85%, GCS 8/15, absent breath sounds. What is the next step? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Secure airway, ICD placement, and IV fluids

 

Following ATLS principles (A, B, C, D):

 

  • GCS 8/15 ("GCS below 8, intubate") indicates need for immediate airway protection
  • SpO2 85% with absent breath sounds suggests respiratory compromise needing ICD
  • BP 90 mmHg indicates a need for fluid resuscitation. This option follows the correct sequence of resuscitation:
    • Airway (A)
    • Breathing (B) - ICD placement
    • Circulation (C) - IV fluids

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Start IV fluids, give atropine and send for chest x-ray:

 

  • Skips airway management in a patient with GCS 8/15
  • Atropine not indicated in this scenario
  • Imaging should not precede resuscitation

 

Option C. Administer IV Dextrose and send for CT:

 

  • Neglects immediate airway and breathing issues
  • CT scan inappropriate before stabilization
  • IV dextrose not indicated in acute trauma

 

Option D. Evaluate for head injury and perform surgery:

 

  • Ignores immediate airway and breathing concerns
  • Surgery evaluation premature before stabilization
  • Violates ATLS principles of prioritization

 

Educational Objective: 


In trauma, follow ABCDE sequence.

choices.text: Active Na+ reabsorption, passive CI- reabsorption, passive K+ secretion, active secretion of HCO3-
Passive Na+ reabsorption, active CI- reabsorption, passive K+ secretion, active secretion of HCO3-
Passive Na+ secretion, active CI- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, passive secretion of HCO3-
Active Na+ reabsorption, passive CI- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, passive secretion of HCO3-

questions.text: The second phase of saliva secretion involves: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Active Na+ reabsorption, passive CI- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, passive secretion of HCO3-

 

First, sodium ions are actively reabsorbed from all the salivary ducts and potassium ions are actively secreted in exchange for the sodium. Excess sodium reabsorption over potassium secretion, creates electrical negativity of about -70 millivolts in the salivary ducts; this in turn causes chloride ions to be reabsorbed passively. Therefore, the chloride ion concentration in the salivary fluid falls to a very low level, matching the ductal decrease in sodium ion concentration.

 

Active Na+ reabsorption

 

(The ductal cells actively transport sodium ions (Na+) from the saliva into the interstitial fluid surrounding the ducts. This reabsorption of sodium ions helps in concentrating the saliva). Conc.  15 mEq/L

              ↓

Passive Cl- reabsorption

(As sodium ions are reabsorbed, chloride ions (Cl-) passively follow along due to electrical charge balance. This results in the reabsorption of chloride ions from the saliva into the interstitial fluid). Conc.  15 mEq/L

              ↓

Active K+ secretion

(The ductal cells actively secrete potassium ions (K+) into the saliva. This secretion helps in maintaining the concentration of potassium ions within the saliva). Conc.  30 mEq/L

              ↓

Passive secretion of HCO3-

(Hydrogen carbonate ions (HCO3-) are passively secreted from the ductal cells into the saliva. This helps in maintaining the alkaline nature of saliva, which aids in buffering acidic substances and maintaining oral pH). Conc. 50 to 70 mEq/L,

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Active Na+ reabsorption, passive Cl- reabsorption, passive K+ secretion, active secretion of HCO3-: Incorrect. While Na+ and Cl- processes are correct, K+ secretion is active, not passive.

 

Option B. Passive Na+ reabsorption, active Cl- reabsorption, passive K+ secretion, active secretion of HCO3-: Incorrect. Na+ reabsorption and Cl- reabsorption roles are reversed, and K+ secretion is active.

 

Option C. Passive Na+ secretion, active Cl- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, passive secretion of HCO3-: Incorrect. Na+ reabsorption should be active, not passive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The second phase of saliva secretion involves active Na+ reabsorption, passive Cl- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, and passive secretion of HCO3-, crucial for maintaining electrolyte balance and pH in saliva.

questions.text: Which artery is used for AV shunting with the great saphenous vein for hemodialysis and is present behind the medial malleolus and 2.5 cm in front of the tendon calcaneus? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior tibial artery

 

The posterior tibial artery is located behind the medial malleolus and is commonly used in arteriovenous (AV) shunting with the great saphenous vein for hemodialysis access. This artery runs in the posterior compartment of the leg and is palpable behind the medial malleolus, approximately 2.5 cm anterior to the tendon calcaneus (Achilles tendon). It is a reliable location for vascular access because of its relatively superficial position and ease of palpation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Peroneal artery: The peroneal artery is located in the lateral compartment of the leg and does not course near the medial malleolus, making it unsuitable for the AV shunting procedure described in the question.

 

Option B. Anterior tibial artery: The anterior tibial artery is located on the anterior aspect of the leg and passes between the medial and lateral malleoli, where it is palpable in front of the ankle joint. It is not positioned behind the medial malleolus, hence it is not the correct answer.

 

Option C. Dorsalis pedis artery: The dorsalis pedis artery is palpable on the dorsum of the foot near the navicular bone or intermediate cuneiform, far from the medial malleolus and tendon calcaneus. Therefore, it is not used for AV shunting as described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The posterior tibial artery is the artery located behind the medial malleolus and is commonly used for AV shunting with the great saphenous vein in procedures like hemodialysis access due to its superficial location and ease of access.

questions.text: The sequence of color change in Raynaud’s disease: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) White - Blue - Red

 

Explanation:

 

Raynaud's disease follows a characteristic sequence of color changes in the digits. The phenomenon shows a typical pattern: first, the digits turn white (pallor/syncope) due to arteriolar constriction; then they become blue/cyanotic (asphyxia) as capillaries dilate and fill with deoxygenated blood; finally, they turn red (reactive hyperemia) when arterioles relax and oxygenated blood returns to the dilated capillaries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Red - Blue - White This sequence is incorrect. The initial phase of Raynaud's is vasoconstriction causing pallor (white), not redness. The arterial supply is initially shut down, not increased.

 

Option C. White - Red - Blue This sequence is incorrect. After the initial white phase, blood stagnates in the capillaries leading to cyanosis (blue), not redness. Red is the final recovery phase.

 

Option D. Red - White - Blue This is the complete reverse of the correct sequence and physiologically impossible in Raynaud's disease. The condition begins with vasoconstriction (white), not vasodilation (red).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Raynaud's disease manifests with a pathognomonic triple-color change sequence (white-blue-red) corresponding to the pathophysiological stages of vasospasm: initial vasoconstriction (pallor), followed by capillary dilatation with deoxygenated blood (cyanosis), and finally arteriolar relaxation with return of oxygenated blood (erythema).

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true regarding memantine? (INICET NOV 2022)
 

1. Its therapeutic effect is due to its antagonistic action on NMDA receptors.
 

2. It is reserved for moderate-to-severe cases of Alzheimer’s disease.
 

3. It is used only as a monotherapy and should not be used with cholinesterase inhibitors.
 

4. It is given at a daily dose of 20-30 mg/day.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1, 2

 

1. Its therapeutic effect is due to its antagonistic action on NMDA receptors: True. Memantine is an NMDA (N-methyl-D-aspartate) receptor antagonist. It works by blocking the action of glutamate at the NMDA receptors, which is thought to play a role in the symptoms of Alzheimer's disease.

 

2. It is reserved for moderate-to-severe cases of Alzheimer’s disease: True. Memantine is typically used in the treatment of moderate to severe Alzheimer's disease. It is not commonly used in the early stages of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

3. It is used only as a monotherapy and should not be used with cholinesterase inhibitors: False. Memantine can be used alone (as monotherapy) or in combination with cholinesterase inhibitors, such as donepezil, rivastigmine, or galantamine, in the treatment of Alzheimer's disease.

 

4. It is given at a daily dose of 20-30 mg/day: False. Memantine is started at a lower dose of 5 mg daily and is titrated up to a target dose, which is usually 20 mg/day. Therefore, it is more precise to say that the standard dose is up to 20 mg/day.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Memantine is an NMDA receptor antagonist used for moderate to severe Alzheimer's disease. It can be used alone or in combination with cholinesterase inhibitors, and the standard maximum dose is 20 mg/day.

questions.text: Apixaban belongs to which of the following class of drugs? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Factor Xa inhibitor

 

Apixaban is an oral direct factor Xa inhibitor. Other examples of this class of drug includes Rivaroxaban and Edoxaban.

 

It is the DOC for the treatment and prophylaxis of DVT, also for prophylaxis of thrombosis in monovalvular atrial fibrillation (except for severe mitral stenosis where Warfarin is used).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antifibrinolytic: Antifibrinolytics, such as tranexamic acid, work by inhibiting the breakdown of fibrin, stabilizing clots. Apixaban does not belong to this class.

 

Option C. Oral direct thrombin inhibitor: Oral direct thrombin inhibitors, such as dabigatran, directly inhibit thrombin (Factor IIa). Apixaban does not inhibit thrombin directly; it inhibits Factor Xa.

 

Option D. Parenteral direct thrombin inhibitor: Parenteral direct thrombin inhibitors, such as argatroban and bivalirudin, are administered intravenously and inhibit thrombin directly. Apixaban is not administered parenterally and does not directly inhibit thrombin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Apixaban is an oral direct Factor Xa inhibitor used for the prevention and treatment of thromboembolic events, including deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and thromboembolism in nonvalvular atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: Bleeding as shown in the image is due to which of the following vessels?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bridging veins

 

The image demonstrating a bleed over the arachnoid layer but beneath the dura suggests a subdural hemorrhage. It is most commonly caused by the shearing of cortical bridging veins.

 

A subdural hemorrhage is a type of intracranial hemorrhage, which is bleeding within the skull. It occurs when blood accumulates between the dura mater (the tough outermost layer of the meninges) and the arachnoid mater (the middle layer of the meninges) surrounding the brain.

 

Subdural hemorrhages are usually caused by trauma to the head, such as falls or motor vehicle accidents, which can tear the veins that bridge the dura and arachnoid layers. The bleeding can create pressure on the brain, leading to neurological symptoms such as headaches, confusion, dizziness, seizures, and in severe cases, coma or death.

 

The symptoms of a subdural hemorrhage can develop immediately or may take hours or even days to appear, depending on the severity of the bleeding. In some cases, a small subdural hemorrhage may resolve on its own without treatment, while larger or more severe bleeds may require surgery to relieve pressure on the brain and stop the bleeding.

 

Factors that can increase the risk of a subdural hemorrhage include advanced age, alcohol or drug abuse, blood-thinning medications, and medical conditions that affect blood clotting or increase the risk of falls. Early recognition and treatment of a subdural hemorrhage can improve outcomes and prevent complications.

 

Dx:- Non-Contrast CT is the investigation of choice.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Middle meningeal artery rupture would result in an extradural hemorrhage.

 

Option C. Lenticulostriate artery would lead to an intraparenchymal hemorrhage.

 

Option D. Vertebral artery dissection leads to subarachnoid hemorrhage or sometimes intraparenchymal hemorrhage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognition of a subdural hemorrhage is crucial following head trauma, especially in individuals at higher risk such as the elderly, those on anticoagulation therapy, or those with a history of alcohol abuse. Immediate medical evaluation is vital to manage the condition effectively and mitigate potential severe outcomes.

choices.text: The surgeon must use chromic catgut.
The surgeon must not include the submucosa in the sutures.
The surgeon must use the single layer, extramucosal suture technique.
The surgeon must use the single- layer seromuscular suture technique.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the hospital with symptoms of an inguinal hernia. During the operation, the surgeon observes a segment of necrotic bowel in the hernial sac. What is the appropriate course of action for resection and anastomosis of a necrotic bowel seen during surgery? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. The surgeon must use the single layer, extramucosal suture technique.

 

The single-layer, extramucosal suture technique of Halstead involves using a single layer of sutures to join the two ends of the bowel together, while avoiding the mucosal layer. This technique is less time-consuming than the double-layer technique and reduces the risk of complications such as bleeding, stricture formation, and anastomotic leak. This is one of the preferred techniques in small bowel anastomosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The surgeon must use chromic catgut:  Chromic catgut is a type of absorbable suture that is made from the collagen found in sheep or goat intestine. Chromic catgut has a relatively short duration of tensile strength, and so it is not recommended for use in areas of high tension or stress, including intestinal anastomosis.

 

Option B. The surgeon must not include the submucosa in the sutures: The submucosa is a layer of tissue beneath the mucosal lining of the bowel. It should be included in sutures as it is the toughest layer of the bowel.

 

Option D. The surgeon must use the single-layer seromuscular suture technique: The single-layer seromuscular suture technique involves suturing the seromuscular layer of the bowel to join the two ends together. This technique is quick and easy to perform but may not be suitable for all cases as it can increase the risk of anastomotic leakage and stenosis. Therefore, it is important to assess each case individually and choose the appropriate technique based on the specific circumstances.

 

Educational Objective:


The single-layer extramucosal suture technique is the preferred method in small bowel anastomosis to reduce complications such as bleeding, strictures, and anastomotic leaks.

questions.text: You are a public health researcher evaluating a new screening test for early detection of a specific disease in a community. Your team successfully conducted a pilot study in a small group. Before planning a large-scale implementation, you wish to ensure that the findings from your pilot study can be applied to larger, diverse groups of individuals outside your initial sample. This ability to extrapolate the findings in the broader population, i.e. the external validity of a screening test is related to which of the following options? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Generalizability

 

  • Generalizability refers to the extent to which the findings from a study or pilot test can be applied to a broader population.
  • It is a measure of the external validity of a study.
  • Ensuring that the results of a pilot study can be extrapolated to larger, diverse groups outside the initial sample is crucial for the success of large-scale implementations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stability: Refers to the consistency of test results over time, ensuring that repeated measurements yield the same results under unchanged conditions. While important, it does not address how findings apply to different populations.

 

Option B. Objectivity: Ensures that test results are unbiased and not influenced by the person administering the test. While critical for reliable results, it does not relate to applying findings to a broader population.

 

Option D. Repeatability: Refers to the consistency of the test results when repeated under identical conditions. This is crucial for reliability but does not address the applicability of the results to different populations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

External validity of a screening test is related to generalizability.

 

Validity refers to what extent the test measures which it purports to measure (adequacy of measurement).

 

Types of Validity

questions.text: The sulcus located deep to the marked structure is? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stem of the lateral sulcus

 

 

  • The marked structure in the image points to the region where the parietal lobe and temporal lobe meet. This region is associated with the lateral sulcus, also known as the Sylvian fissure. The stem of the lateral sulcus is located deep to this marked structure, separating the frontal and parietal lobes from the temporal lobe.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central sulcus: Incorrect. The central sulcus separates the frontal lobe from the parietal lobe and is not located in the region marked in the image.

 

Option C. Inferior frontal sulcus: Incorrect. This sulcus is found on the lateral surface of the frontal lobe and does not correspond to the marked region.

 

Option D. Superior temporal sulcus: Incorrect. This sulcus runs parallel to the lateral sulcus on the temporal lobe, but it is not deep to the marked structure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The stem of the lateral sulcus is located deep to the marked structure in the image, which is a critical landmark in neuroanatomy for separating the frontal and parietal lobes from the temporal lobe.

questions.text: Identify the structure which is responsible for elevation and is supplied by the nerve emergency from the structure shown in the image? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Risorius

 

Explanation:

 

Risorius is supplied by the facial nerve, resulting in the marked elevation. The image depicts the floor of the fourth ventricle, as well as the facial colliculus.

 

 

The facial colliculus is a raised area on the floor of the fourth ventricle in the brainstem, and it is associated with the motor nucleus of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). The facial nerve is responsible for the motor innervation of the muscles of facial expression, including the risorius muscle, which is one of the muscles that can cause elevation of the corner of the mouth in smiling. Therefore, the structure that is supplied by the nerve causing this elevation would be the risorius muscle.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral rectus: Is an extraocular muscle that arises from the lateral part of the common tendinous ring. It is innervated by the abducens nerve.

 

Option B. Superior oblique: Is an extraocular muscle that arises from the body of the sphenoid. It is innervated by the trochlear nerve.

 

Option D. Levator palpebrae superioris: The levator palpebrae superioris muscle is supplied by the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III). This muscle is responsible for raising the upper eyelid (levator means "elevator"), allowing you to open your eyes.

 

The oculomotor nerve also innervates several other muscles that control eye movement and pupil constriction, making it an important cranial nerve for eye function

 

Educational Objective:

 

The risorius muscle, responsible for pulling the corner of the mouth laterally and aiding in expressions like smiling, is innervated by the facial nerve.

questions.text: Which of these disorders was earlier known as minimal brain dysfunction?  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder

 

Attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) was earlier referred to as minimal brain dysfunction. ADHD is characterized by symptoms of inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dyslexia is a specific learning disorder that affects reading, despite normal intelligence. It is characterized by difficulties with accurate and/or fluent word recognition and by poor spelling and decoding abilities.

 

Option C. Mental sub normality is an outdated term, previously used to describe intellectual disabilities or developmental delays.

 

Option D. Oligophrenia is an old term that was used to describe intellectual disability or mental retardation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ADHD, formerly known as minimal brain dysfunction, is characterized by symptoms of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity. Diagnosis requires symptoms before age 12 in multiple settings. Treatment commonly involves stimulant medications and behavioral therapy.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 1171.

questions.text: In the adjoining image of the muscle fiber action potential, the phase marked B is due to which of the following? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Efflux of potassium

 

The phase marked B in the muscle fiber action potential graph typically represents the repolarization phase of the action potential.

 

During repolarization, potassium channels open, allowing K+ to flow out of the cell, which returns the membrane potential back toward its resting value.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Influx of potassium: Influx of K+ occurs during the resting condition by Na+ K+ Pump, not during the repolarization phase of an action potential.

 

Option C. Sodium efflux: Sodium (Na+) influx, not efflux, is responsible for the depolarization phase (Not for the repolarization), where the membrane potential rapidly rises, preceding phase B.

 

Option D. Calcium influx: Calcium influx is more related to the initiation of muscle contraction following the depolarization phase, not directly related to the action potential of nerve or repolarization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The repolarization phase of a muscle fiber action potential is primarily due to the efflux of potassium ions (K+) from the cell, which restores the membrane potential to its resting state.

choices.text: Increase in myocardial oxygen consumption is seen with increased pressure work than volume
Aortic stenosis causes reduced pressure at the aortic valve
Workload has nothing to do with myocardial oxygen consumption
Increased pressure - Increase in preload more than afterload

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presented with dyspnea and chest pain. Which of the following proves that she has aortic stenosis rather than aortic regurgitation? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increase in myocardial oxygen consumption is seen with increased pressure work than volume

 

In cases of aortic stenosis, the primary issue is the increased afterload due to the obstruction in the aortic valve, which forces the left ventricle to work harder to push blood against the increased resistance. This increased pressure work leads to higher myocardial oxygen consumption because the heart needs more energy to overcome the obstruction. The increase in pressure work (afterload) is significantly more in aortic stenosis than in aortic regurgitation, where volume overload (preload) is more prominent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aortic stenosis causes reduced pressure at the aortic valve: This statement is incorrect because aortic stenosis actually increases the pressure at the aortic valve due to the obstruction, not reduces it.

 

Option C. Workload has nothing to do with myocardial oxygen consumption: This is incorrect. Myocardial oxygen consumption is directly related to the workload of the heart. Increased workload, especially due to pressure overload in conditions like aortic stenosis, results in higher oxygen consumption.

 

Option D. Increased pressure - Increase in preload more than afterload: This is incorrect because in aortic stenosis, the afterload (pressure) is more significantly increased than the preload. Preload (end-diastolic volume) is typically increased in conditions like aortic regurgitation, not aortic stenosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aortic stenosis is characterized by increased pressure work (afterload) leading to higher myocardial oxygen consumption, distinguishing it from aortic regurgitation, which is associated with volume overload (preload).

questions.text: A male patient who just lost his work felt irritated and depressed for the majority of the time. Thinking about the future troubled him, and he was irritated with his family members. He went out to see movies with his friends on occasion and was able to enjoy himself, but when he returned home, he experienced identical sensations. What's the most likely diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adjustment disorder

 

The patient's symptoms – depressive mood, irritability, and worry about the future – began after a clear stressor, which in this case is the loss of his job. While he has some features of depression, the ability to temporarily feel better, such as when seeing movies with friends, makes a major depressive episode less likely.

 

This disorder arises within three months of a particular stressor (e.g., job loss) and resolves within six months after the stressor ends or the individual adapts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Generalized anxiety disorder: Chronic worry is a feature, but there is usually no specific identifiable stressor or precipitant, and the duration of symptoms should be at least 6 months.

 

Option C. Mixed anxiety with depression: This isn’t a specific DSM-5 diagnosis. While the patient has symptoms of both, the clear onset after job loss points more towards adjustment disorder.

 

Option D. Moderate depression: The patient’s ability to still experience pleasure (e.g., enjoying movies) makes a full depressive episode less likely.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Adjustment disorder is characterized by emotional responses to stressful events like financial problems, medical illness, relationship problems or death of a loved one. It manifests with emotional or behavioral symptoms which include depressed mood, anxiety, worry, a feeling of inability to cope and some degree of disturbance in individuals daily functioning. The symptoms typically remit within 6 months if the stressor has ended. Treatment of choice is supportive psychotherapy.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 112.

questions.text: Which segment of the vertebrae is involved in a patient presenting with pain in the back of the thigh and the leg after lifting heavy weight? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) S1


The S1 nerve root is commonly involved when a patient presents with pain radiating to the back of the thigh and the leg, especially after activities such as lifting heavy weights. S1 supplies the lateral part of the sole, the small toe, and the lateral aspect of the foot, which aligns with the typical presentation of pain distribution in such cases. The S1 dermatome covers the area from the back of the thigh down to the lateral part of the leg and foot.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. S2: While S2 is also located in the lower limb region, it primarily affects the posterior aspect of the thigh and the gluteal region rather than extending into the leg and foot. The symptoms described in the question align more closely with S1 involvement.

 

Option C. L5: The L5 nerve root affects the lateral thigh, anterior shin, and top of the foot, including the big toe. Pain in this dermatome does not typically extend to the back of the thigh and leg as described.

 

Option D. L4: The L4 nerve root typically affects the anterior thigh and the medial aspect of the shin. It does not extend to the back of the thigh or the lateral part of the leg and foot.

 

Educational Objective:


The S1 nerve root is involved in pain radiating to the back of the thigh and leg, especially affecting the lateral part of the foot and the small toe, common in cases of heavy lifting or nerve compression.

questions.text:
Organize the listed bands within the sarcomere, starting from the periphery and moving towards the center. (INICET MAY 2023)

 

 

  1. Z line
  2. M line
  3. A band
  4. H zone
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1,3,4,2

 

The proper order of bands within the sarcomere, moving from the periphery towards the center, is as follows: Z line - I band - A band - H zone - M line.

 

 

Z line: A dense protein structure that separates one sarcomere from the next and serves as an anchor for actin filaments.

 

I band: The light-colored region in a sarcomere composed of only thin actin filaments.

 

A band: The dark-colored region in a sarcomere containing both thick myosin and thin actin filaments.

 

H zone: The central part of the A band where only thick myosin filaments are present.

 

M line: The center of the sarcomere, providing structural support and anchoring the myosin filaments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct order of bands within the sarcomere, from the periphery towards the center, is Z line, A band, H zone, and M line.

choices.text: Subthalamic nuclei
Globus pallidus

questions.text: A 65-year-old man suffered from a stroke 2 days ago. He now presents with involuntary, violent, and flinging movements of the limbs on one side. What is the likely site of lesion in this patient?   (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Subthalamic nuclei

 

Explanation

 

Most probable diagnosis as per the clinical history is hemiballismus which is caused by a lesion in subthalamic nuclei.

 

Hemiballismus is a disorder characterized by violent involuntary abnormal movements on one side of the body involving mostly the arm. While walking, the arm swings widely. These movements are called the flinging movements. These movements are due to the release phenomenon because of the absence of inhibitory influence on movements. Hemiballismus occurs due to degeneration of subthalamic nucleus of Luys.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Globus pallidus: Incorrect for hemiballismus. Lesions here typically result in different forms of dyskinesia, such as parkinsonism or dystonia, but not hemiballismus.

 

Option C. Putamen: Also incorrect for this symptom. While putamen lesions are involved in many movement disorders, like Huntington's disease and some forms of Parkinson's disease, they do not typically cause hemiballismus.

 

Option D. Caudate nucleus: Incorrect. Lesions in the caudate nucleus are more often associated with Huntington's disease, which leads to chorea—rapid, jerky movements—not the large-amplitude flinging movements seen in hemiballismus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient presenting with unilateral flinging, violent limb movements following a stroke, the subthalamic nuclei should be considered as the primary site of lesion. This knowledge is crucial for accurate diagnosis and guiding treatment decisions, such as the use of neuroleptics or other interventions to control these disruptive movements.

questions.text: A young patient began taking a weight loss medication that works by preventing fat absorption from food. She developed easy bruising and increased menstrual bleeding after a few weeks. Which of the following vitamins deficiency is likely to be responsible for her condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin K

 

  • Vitamin A, D, E and K are fat soluble vitamins. Their absorption is hampered when the absorption of fat is prevented by a medication (eg Orlistat , Ezetimibe etc).
  • Vitamin K is required for the Gamma carboxylation of Glutamic acid residues of clotting factors 2 ,7 ,9 and 10 in order to activate them. If Vitamin K is deficient due to fat malabsorption, as in the above case, then there can be bleeding manifestations in the form of easy bruising and increased menstrual bleeding in females. The Prothrombin Time (PT) will be elevated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin E: Vitamin E deficiency can manifest as hemolytic anemia.

 

Option C. Vitamin B6: Vitamin B6 deficiency can be seen with drugs like Isoniazid, Penicillamine, Hydralazine, OCP. Patients can have peripheral neuritis, lowered seizure threshold, or convulsions.

 

Option D. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency leads to the development of rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin K deficiency due to impaired fat absorption from weight loss medications can lead to bleeding manifestations such as easy bruising and increased menstrual bleeding.

choices.text: Cessation of calcium release from sarcoplasm
Attachment of ATP to myosin head

questions.text: What leads to the detachment of myosin from actin filaments during muscle contraction? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Attachment of ATP to myosin head

 

Binding of ATP to the myosin head is what leads to the detachment of the myosin head from the actin filament during muscle contraction. The process of muscle contraction involves several steps where ATP plays a crucial role:

 

  1. Attachment of ATP: An ATP molecule binds to the myosin head, causing it to detach from the actin filament.
  2. Hydrolysis of ATP: The myosin head, which has ATPase activity, hydrolyzes ATP into ADP and inorganic phosphate (Pi). This hydrolysis provides the energy required for the myosin head to return to its high-energy, cocked position.
  3. Cross-bridge formation: The myosin head binds to a new position on the actin filament.
  4. Power stroke: The release of ADP and Pi from the myosin head triggers the power stroke, where the myosin head pivots and pulls the actin filament, causing muscle contraction.
  5. Repeat cycle: The cycle repeats as long as ATP is available and calcium ions are present to keep the binding sites on actin exposed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dissociation of ADP and Pi: This is involved in the power stroke, not in the detachment of myosin from actin.

 

Option B. Cessation of calcium release from sarcoplasm: This leads to muscle relaxation by causing the tropomyosin to cover the binding sites on actin, not directly to the detachment of myosin from actin.

 

Option C. Conformational change in Troponin T: This occurs when calcium binds to troponin, allowing tropomyosin to move away from the binding sites on actin, not directly related to detachment of myosin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The detachment of myosin from actin filaments during muscle contraction is caused by the binding of ATP to the myosin head, which allows the myosin head to release from the actin and prepare for another cycle of contraction.

choices.text: ANOVA is an example of a non-parametric test
It is used for skewed distributions
It involves the assumption that the data has a normal distribution
It cannot be used for small sample sizes

questions.text: Which of the following is true for non-parametric tests? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) It is used for skewed distributions 

 

  • Non-parametric tests are statistical tests that do not require the data to be normally distributed or have a specific population parameter, such as the mean or variance, assumed beforehand. They are typically used when the data are not normally distributed, have outliers, or when the sample size is small.
  • Some examples of non-parametric tests include the Wilcoxon rank-sum test, Kruskal-Wallis test, and Mann-Whitney U test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ANOVA is an example of a non-parametric test:  Is incorrect because ANOVA is a parametric test used to compare the means of two or more groups.

 

Option C. It involves the assumption that the data has a normal distribution: Is incorrect because non-parametric tests do not assume that the data has a normal distribution.

 

Option D. It cannot be used for small sample sizes: Is also incorrect because non-parametric tests can be used for small sample sizes. In fact, they are often preferred over parametric tests for small sample sizes or when the assumptions of parametric tests are violated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-parametric tests are valuable statistical tools when dealing with skewed distributions or when the assumptions of parametric tests (like normal distribution) are not met. They provide robustness against the distribution shape of the data and are effective in handling smaller sample sizes and outliers.

questions.text: Identify the procedure shown in the image below. (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dog ear correction

 

The image demonstrates dog ear correction, a technique used to address redundant tissue that forms at the ends of a sutured wound. Dog ears occur when there are unequal wound edges or improper wound closure angles. The procedure involves excising the excess triangular skin fold at a 45-degree angle (as shown in panel 1), then removing the redundant tissue (panel 2), and finally achieving a flat, cosmetically acceptable closure (panel 3). The interrupted sutures shown are typical for this correction. This bunching of tissue resembles a dog's ear, hence the name. The technique ensures a smooth, flat scar without protruding tissue at the wound ends.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incision and drainage of abscess: Incorrect. Incision and drainage involves making a linear or cruciate incision to evacuate pus from an abscess cavity. The image shows excision of redundant skin with primary closure, not drainage of any collection.

 

Option B. Skin grafting: Incorrect. Skin grafting involves harvesting skin from a donor site and transplanting it to cover a defect. The image shows direct excision and primary closure without any graft placement.

 

Option C. Keloid excision: Incorrect. Keloid excision involves removing hypertrophic scar tissue that extends beyond the original wound boundaries. The image shows correction of redundant normal skin at wound edges, not pathological scar tissue removal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dog ear deformity is corrected by excising redundant tissue at 45-degree angles at the wound ends when unequal wound edges create tissue bunching during closure.

questions.text: Match the following? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-2, B-4, C-1, D-3

 

Explanation:

 

Twilight (A) refers to a transient, impaired state of consciousness often seen during seizures or certain other medical conditions. Therefore, it matches with Impaired level of consciousness (2).

 

Oneroid state (B) is a term used in psychiatry to describe a dream-like state of consciousness, hence matching with Oneirophrenia (4), which is derived from the words meaning 'dream' and 'mind'.

 

Oligophrenia (C) is an outdated medical term used to describe intellectual disability or subnormal intelligence. Thus, it matches with Subnormal intelligence (1).

 

Paranoid Ideation (D) involves thoughts dominated by ideas of persecution or conspiracy against the individual. This matches with Persecution (3).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Oneroid state is characterized by a dream-like state resembling Oneirophrenia. Oligophrenia refers to intellectual disability, and Paranoid Ideation is centered on ideas of persecution.

 

Reference: Sim’s symptoms in the Mind, 7th edition, Page No 39, 40, 132; Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 4599.

questions.text: Testosterone is secreted by? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Leydig cells

 

Leydig cells are specialized cells located within the testes that are responsible for the production of testosterone, the primary male sex hormone. This process is regulated by luteinizing hormone (LH), which is released from the anterior pituitary gland.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anterior Pituitary: Incorrect because the anterior pituitary secretes LH and FSH (Follicle Stimulating Hormone), which regulate the function of Leydig and Sertoli cells, respectively, but it does not directly secrete testosterone.

 

Option C. From the conversion of dihydrotestosterone: Incorrect as dihydrotestosterone (DHT) is actually derived from testosterone via the action of the enzyme 5α-reductase, primarily in peripheral tissues.

 

Option D. From Sertoli cells: Incorrect because Sertoli cells produce inhibin and androgen-binding protein under the stimulation of FSH, not testosterone.

 

Additional Information

 

  • Two-Cell–Two-Gonadotropin Theory: This theory explains the interaction between Leydig and Sertoli cells in the testes. LH stimulates Leydig cells to produce testosterone, while FSH stimulates Sertoli cells to produce inhibin and androgen-binding globulin, which help regulate the effects of testosterone on spermatogenesis.
  • Negative Feedback Regulation: Testosterone exerts negative feedback on the hypothalamus and anterior pituitary to inhibit the secretion of LH, and inhibin specifically inhibits FSH secretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Testosterone is primarily produced by Leydig cells in the testes, under the regulation of LH from the anterior pituitary. This hormone is crucial for the development of male reproductive tissues, secondary sexual characteristics, and several other physiological functions such as muscle mass maintenance, bone density, and mood regulation.

questions.text: Boundaries of Calot triangle are formed by all except? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Gall bladder

 

The gallbladder itself does not form a boundary of Calot's triangle. Instead, it's closely related to the triangle, being situated just adjacent to it.

 

It's an important landmark in cholecystectomy (surgical removal of the gallbladder) because of the structures that it contains. The identification of this triangle helps to prevent injury to the common bile duct during surgery.

 

  • Boundaries of Calot's triangle is bounded:
    • Medially/Left side - Common hepatic duct
    • Right side/ Laterally   Cystic duct
    • Superior - lower surface of liver
    • Contents of calot’s triangle - Cystic artery and lymph node of lund 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Common hepatic duct: This forms the inferior boundary of Calot's triangle. The common hepatic duct is the duct formed by the joining of the left and right hepatic ducts. It later joins the cystic duct to form the common bile duct.

 

Option B. Cystic duct: This duct connects the gallbladder to the common hepatic duct and subsequently forms the common bile duct. The cystic duct forms the lateral boundary of Calot's triangle.

 

Option C. Cystic artery: Inferior surface of liver forms the superior boundary of calot’s triangle

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatocystic triangle and triangle of Calot - Hepatocystic triangle (blue): Upper boundary of hepatocystic triangle is the inferior border of liver. Lateral, the cystic duct and the neck of the gallbladder. Medial, the common hepatic duct.

choices.text: Tablet alprazolam 0.5 mg once a day before bedtime for 7 days
Tablet alprazolam 0.5 mg HS for 7 days
Tablet alprazolam 500 mcg one tablet OD for 7 days
Tablet alprazolam ½ mg tablet HS daily

questions.text: As an Indian medical intern, which of the following is the correct format for prescription of alprazolam? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tablet alprazolam 0.5 mg once a day before bedtime for 7 days

 

IMPORTANT POINTS REGARDING PRESCRIPTION WRITING:

 

  • Prescription is invalid without date and signature of the doctor.
  • Drug name should never been written in abbreviation form (e.g. never write PCM for paracetamol).
  • Abbreviations like OD, BD, HS etc should not be used in prescription.
  • Leading zeros should always be mentioned (e.g. 0.5 mg is correct but .5 mg is incorrect)
  • Trail zeros should never be written (e.g. 5 mg is correct but 5.0 is incorrect).
  • Microgram should be written as mcg not as µg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When writing a prescription, always avoid abbreviations for dosage instructions, use clear and complete language, include leading zeros for dosages less than one, and avoid trailing zeros. The correct format ensures clarity and safety for the patient.

choices.text: Attached to the inner border of 2nd rib
Attached with transverse process of C7

questions.text: Which among the following statement is incorrect regarding Sibson’s fascia? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Attached to the inner border of 2nd rib

 

Sibson's fascia is joined to the first rib's inner border, not the second rib.

 

Sibson's fascia (suprapleural membrane)

 

  • Covers the apical portion of the lung and acts as a dividing line between the lower neck and the thorax.
  • It is attached to the inner border of the 1st rib and posteriorly to the anterior border of the transverse process of the C7 vertebra.
  • It is strengthened by a few spreading muscular fibers derived from the scalene muscles.
  • The subclavian vessels lie on top of it.

 

Clinical significance

 

  • The suprapleural membrane's function is to protect the apex of the lung (the part that extends outside the rib cage) and the cervical fascia. This aids in resisting intrathoracic pressure changes, preventing neck inflation and deflation during expiration and inspiration, and also providing rigidity to the thoracic inlet.
  • Herniation of the cervical fascia may result due to injury to suprapleural membrane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Covers apical part of lung (Correct): Sibson's fascia covers the apical (uppermost) part of the lung and helps separate the cervical pleura from the surrounding structures.

 

Option C. Attached with transverse process of C7 (Correct): Sibson's fascia is posteriorly attached with the tip of the transverse process of C7.

 

Option D. Vessels pass above the fascia (Correct): Blood vessels, including the subclavian vessels, pass above Sibson's fascia as they enter and exit the thoracic cavity. This fascia serves as a landmark for the placement of central venous catheters, as it delineates the boundary between the cervical and thoracic regions.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sibson's fascia is not directly attached to the inner border of the 2nd rib. Instead, it is associated with the cervical pleura and extends superiorly to attach to the transverse process of the 7th cervical (C7) vertebra. It forms the outer boundary of the cervicothoracic (suprapleural) space.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is oxygen therapy not useful? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Central respiratory depression

 

Explanation 

 

Oxygen therapy is not beneficial in central respiratory depression, as oxygen therapy will reduce the hypoxic drive to breathe further depressing the respiratory frequency and minute ventilation.



 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Asthma: Because oxygen therapy can be crucial in severe asthma attacks where it helps alleviate hypoxia.

 

Option B. Acute myocardial infarction: As oxygen therapy is often used to increase oxygen delivery to the heart tissue, reducing ischemic damage during an acute myocardial infarction.

 

Option C. Pulmonary edema: Because oxygen therapy helps improve oxygenation in cases of pulmonary edema, especially if caused by heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oxygen therapy is not beneficial in central respiratory depression because it may reduce the hypoxic drive to breathe, potentially further depressing respiratory effort and overall ventilation.

questions.text: Which adult structure is derived from the embryological remnant marked as ‘A’ in the diagram? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Median umbilical ligament

 

Marked structure A is the allantois, which forms the urachus, which in turn gives rise to the median umbilical ligament.

 

The median umbilical ligament represents the remnant of the urachus (also known as the median umbilical fold). The urachus is a tubular structure that connects the fetal bladder to the umbilical cord and allows for the drainage of urine produced by the fetal kidneys into the amniotic fluid.

 

After birth, the urachus becomes non-functional and fibroses to form the median umbilical ligament. It extends from the apex of the bladder to the umbilicus within the median umbilical fold.

 

The given image shows an embryo at the end of the third week.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial umbilical ligament: These are the remnants of the occluded parts of the umbilical arteries. In fetal life, the umbilical arteries arise from the internal iliac arteries and pass to the umbilical cord, carrying deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta.

 

  • In the adult, they persist as the medial umbilical ligaments, which are paired fibrous bands on the inner surface of the anterior abdominal wall, running from the bladder to the umbilicus.

 

Option C. Meckel's diverticulum: Meckel's diverticulum arises from the incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct (or omphalomesenteric duct), which connects the yolk sac to the midgut lumen during embryonic development. It usually disappears by the 7th week of embryonic life.

 

  • If a portion of the vitelline duct remains, it can manifest as a Meckel's diverticulum. It's found in approximately 2% of the population and is often described by the "rule of 2s" - 2 inches long, 2 feet from the ileocecal valve, 2% of the population, and can present with two types of epithelia (gastric and pancreatic).

 

Option D. Ligamentum teres (Round ligament of the liver):

 

  • The ligamentum teres represents the obliterated remnant of the left umbilical vein. During fetal development, the left umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta directly to the fetal heart, bypassing the liver through the ductus venosus.
  • After birth, the need for this shunt ceases, and the ductus venosus along with the left umbilical vein close up. The ligamentum teres runs in the free margin of the falciform ligament, connecting the umbilicus to the anterior aspect of the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: 70 percent of the drug undergoes first pass metabolism in liver.
The drug is 30 percent pure in its chemical composition.
The drug is 30 percent potent in producing therapeutic effect.
30 percent of the drug reaches the systemic circulation in unchanged form

questions.text: What does it mean when a drug has a bioavailability of 30 percent? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans D. 30 percent of the drug reaches the systemic circulation in unchanged form

 

This statement accurately defines bioavailability. Bioavailability is the percentage of an administered drug dose that reaches the systemic circulation without being metabolized or changed. In this case, a bioavailability of 30 percent means that only 30 percent of the drug dose reaches the systemic circulation, while the rest may be eliminated or metabolized before reaching the bloodstream.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 70 percent of the drug undergoes first-pass metabolism in the liver: This statement is not a direct explanation of bioavailability but is related to the fate of the drug after absorption. If 30 percent is bioavailability, then 70 percent of drug is either not absorbed or undergo first pass metabolism. First-pass metabolism in the liver can reduce the amount of drug available for systemic circulation, but it doesn't define bioavailability.

 

Option B. The drug is 30 percent pure in its chemical composition: This statement is incorrect. Bioavailability is not related to the purity of a drug but rather to its absorption and availability in the bloodstream.

 

Option C. The drug is 30 percent potent in producing a therapeutic effect: This statement is not an accurate description of bioavailability. Potency refers to the strength or concentration of a drug required to produce a specific effect, while bioavailability is about how much of the administered dose reaches the systemic circulation.

questions.text: NAPQI is the metabolite of which of the following drug toxicity? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Paracetamol


N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine (NAPQI) is a metabolite of paracetamol drug toxicity.

 

NAPQI is highly reactive and has high affinity for sulfydryl groups. It causes enzymatic dysfunction in the liver. Normally, minor amounts of NAPQI produced in our body are rapidly eliminated by conjugation with reduced glutathione (GSH) that acts as a source of sulfhydryl group and then excreted into the urine.

 

Therefore, paracetamol toxicity is treated with N-acetyl cysteine (NAC), which provides the sulfhydryl group. NAC thereby helps in the excretion of NAPQI from the body.

 

The maximum recommended dose of acetaminophen is 4g/day.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin: Aspirin toxicity is not associated with NAPQI. Aspirin overdose primarily causes metabolic acidosis, respiratory alkalosis, and can lead to salicylate poisoning.

 

Option C. Diclofenac: Diclofenac toxicity does not involve NAPQI. Diclofenac is an NSAID that can cause gastrointestinal and renal toxicity.

 

Option D. Ketorolac: Ketorolac toxicity is not associated with NAPQI. Like other NSAIDs, ketorolac can cause gastrointestinal bleeding and renal toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NAPQI is a toxic metabolite produced during the metabolism of paracetamol. In cases of paracetamol overdose, NAPQI accumulates and causes liver damage. The antidote for paracetamol toxicity is N-acetylcysteine (NAC), which helps detoxify NAPQI by replenishing glutathione and providing sulfhydryl groups.

questions.text: A patient complains of ptosis and increasing muscle weakness by evening. This is relieved by neostigmine. What is the likely diagnosis? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Myasthenia gravis

 

  • A patient complaining of ptosis and increased muscle weakness by the evening, that is relieved by Acetylcholinesterase inhibitor Neostigmine is suggestive of Myasthenia Gravis. Myasthenia gravis is an auto-immune disease due to formation of antibodies against the post synaptic Ach receptors. The characteristic features of muscle weakness with activity and improvement with rest are hallmarks in myasthenia.

  • Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors like Neostigmine and Pyridostigmine lead to an increase in the level of Acetylcholine at the receptor sites, which subsequently leads to an improvement in the muscle function.

  • Edrophonium test is used in the diagnosis of Myasthenia gravis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lambert-Eaton syndrome: This is an autoimmune disorder that affects the voltage-gated calcium channels on the presynaptic membrane, leading to reduced acetylcholine release. It is often associated with small cell lung cancer. Unlike myasthenia gravis, muscle strength may improve with repeated use in Lambert-Eaton syndrome.

 

Option C. Polymyositis: This is an inflammatory myopathy that causes muscle weakness, but it is typically proximal muscle weakness and does not present with ptosis or improvement with acetylcholinesterase inhibitors.

 

Option D. Multiple sclerosis: This is an autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system, leading to demyelination. Symptoms can include muscle weakness, but it typically involves other neurological signs and does not respond to acetylcholinesterase inhibitors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia gravis is characterized by ptosis and muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest. The diagnosis is supported by the relief of symptoms with acetylcholinesterase inhibitors like neostigmine. This condition results from autoantibodies against acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction.

questions.text: A patient came following an RTA in the hospital. He is able to understand his friend’s talks. He is trying to speak (non-fluent aphasia) something to his friend. Which part of the brain is most likely to be injured? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) Broca’s area

 

Explanation:

 

Broca’s area is responsible for speech production and language processing. It is located in the frontal lobe of the dominant hemisphere (usually the left hemisphere) of the brain. Injury to Broca’s area leads to Broca’s aphasia, also known as non-fluent aphasia. Individuals with this condition can understand spoken language but have difficulty in speaking, writing, or forming words properly.

 

Broca’s area: Broca’s aphasia is characterized by difficulty in speech production. The patient may understand speech but will struggle to speak fluently, often speaking in short, broken sentences with considerable effort. This condition is also known as expressive aphasia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wernicke’s area: This area is involved in the comprehension of spoken language. Damage to Wernicke’s area results in Wernicke’s aphasia (fluent aphasia), where the patient can speak fluently but the speech is often nonsensical and lacks meaning.

 

Option B. Angular gyrus: This region is involved in various functions related to language, number processing, and spatial cognition but is not directly responsible for speech production or comprehension.

 

Option D. Arcuate fasciculus: This is a bundle of nerve fibers that connects Broca’s area and Wernicke’s area. Damage to this pathway can result in conduction aphasia, characterized by the ability to understand and produce speech but difficulty in repeating words or sentences.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Broca’s area is involved in speech production. Damage to this area results in non-fluent (expressive) aphasia, where the patient can understand speech but has difficulty speaking fluently.

questions.text: A team of climbers is being briefed about the physiological changes that occur in the body at high altitudes. Which of the following is NOT a typical physiological response seen in individuals at high altitudes?  (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypoventilation

 

Hypoventilation is not a typical response at high altitude. In fact, the opposite occurs - hyperventilation, or increased breathing rate, is a normal physiological response to high altitude to compensate for reduced oxygen availability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polycythemia: Polycythemia, an increase in the number of red blood cells, is a common response to high altitude. It occurs as a compensatory mechanism to improve oxygen carrying capacity due to lower oxygen availability in the atmosphere.

 

Option B. Increase in Hemoglobin (Hb) concentration: An increase in hemoglobin concentration is also a typical response to high altitude. This adaptation helps to enhance the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood.

 

Option C. Increase in myoglobin: There is an increase in myoglobin in muscle tissues at high altitudes. Myoglobin helps in storing oxygen in muscle cells, aiding adaptation to the lower oxygen environment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

At high altitudes, physiological responses include polycythemia, increased hemoglobin concentration, and increased myoglobin, but not hypoventilation.

questions.text: Mrs. Kumar, a 60-year-old woman, has been experiencing difficulty swallowing and a feeling of pressure in her chest. Her doctor orders an ultrasound, which reveals a retrosternal goiter. The commonest surgical approach to a retrosternal goiter is via: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Neck

 

Explanation:

 

The commonest surgical approach to a retrosternal goiter is via the neck. This is because the thyroid gland is anatomically located in the neck, and even when a goiter extends behind the sternum into the chest, the neck provides the most direct and least invasive access for surgical removal. The retrosternal portion of the goiter can usually be mobilized and delivered into the neck for excision without the need for more invasive thoracic approaches. The vascular supply of the goiter also predominantly comes from cervical vessels like the inferior thyroid artery, making the neck approach feasible and effective.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chest: Surgical approaches through the chest are typically not used for retrosternal goiters. Accessing the thyroid gland through the chest would involve more invasive procedures, such as thoracotomy, and is generally reserved for rare cases with specific indications, such as very large goiters extending deeply into the chest cavity.
