Option C. Median Sternotomy: Median sternotomy involves cutting through the breastbone (sternum) to access structures within the chest, particularly the heart and major blood vessels. While median sternotomy is common for cardiac surgeries, it is not the primary approach for treating retrosternal goiters, which can typically be addressed via the neck.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect because the neck is the commonest and preferred approach for the surgical removal of retrosternal goiters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common and preferred surgical approach for a retrosternal goiter is via the neck due to its direct access to the thyroid gland and the feasibility of mobilizing the goiter from this region.

choices.text: N-acetyl cysteine to replenish glutathione stores
Glucagon to control bradycardia and hypoglycemia
Give sodium bicarbonate to alkalize urine

questions.text: A young female is brought to the emergency department. Attendants inform that she has consumed 100 tablets of aspirin. What should be the next step in management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Give sodium bicarbonate to alkalize urine

 

Aspirin poisoning (Salicylism)

 

Respiratory Center Stimulation

↓

Hyperventilation

↓

↓CO2

↓

Respiratory Alkalosis → Reversible

↓

Metabolic Acidosis → Irreversible

 

Treatment - DOC is sodium bicarbonate (NaHC03)

  •  Reverses metabolic acidosis
  •  Helps in aspirin excretion

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. N-acetyl cysteine to replenish glutathione stores: N-acetyl cysteine is an antidote for paracetamol poisoning.

 

Option B. Pralidoxime: Pralidoxime is useful in organophosphate poisoning.

 

Option C. Glucagon to control bradycardia and hypoglycemia: Glucagon is antidote in beta-blocker toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sodium Bicarbonate is the treatment of choice in aspirin poisoning, as it helps to alkalize the urine and enhance the excretion of salicylates, while also correcting metabolic acidosis.

choices.text: Both surface tension and compliance decreased
Both surface tension and compliance increased

questions.text: A preterm baby who was delivered at 28 weeks developed respiratory distress syndrome. Which of the following is true about surface tension and compliance in this baby?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Surface tension - increased; Compliance - decreased

 

Explanation

 

This preterm baby who developed respiratory distress syndrome has surfactant deficiency. Due to which surface tension increases and compliance decreases.

 

Surfactant (Lecithin/Dipalmitoyl phosphatidyl Choline) is produced by specialized cells called type II alveolar cells in the lungs. Surfactant molecules have a hydrophilic (water-attracting) head and a hydrophobic (water-repellent) tail. This unique structure allows surfactant to lower the surface tension at the air-liquid interface of the alveoli. It reduces the attractive forces between water molecules, preventing the alveoli from collapsing during expiration.

 

Compliance refers to the ability of the lungs to expand and recoil efficiently during breathing. Without surfactant, the surface tension within the alveoli would be high, making it difficult for the lungs to inflate during inspiration and causing them to collapse more readily during expiration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In preterm infants, especially those born before the lungs have matured at around 28 weeks, the lack of adequate surfactant leads to increased surface tension and decreased compliance, contributing to the development of respiratory distress syndrome.

choices.text: In children, equally among males and females
In adults, equally among males and females
In adults, occurs more in males than in females
In children, occurs more in females than in males

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presented with sudden-onset blindness for the past 4 hours. However, on history taking, it is noted that she is not concerned about it. However, she is concerned that her mother passed away recently and that she should have spent more time with her. Physical examination findings are normal. Which of the following is true about the condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) In children, occurs more in females than in males

 

The patient is likely experiencing a conversion disorder, also known as functional neurological symptom disorder. It's characterized by neurological symptoms (such as blindness, paralysis, or seizures) that can't be explained by medical evaluation and are presumably linked to psychological factors. The indifference towards the symptom (e.g., not being concerned about sudden blindness) is termed "la belle indifférence," although this feature is not always present.

 

In pediatric populations, females are more commonly affected than males.

 

Other Others:

 

Option A. In children, equally among males and females: Incorrect. In children, the condition is more common in females.

 

Option B. In adults, equally among males and females: Incorrect. In adults, conversion disorder is more common in females than in males.

 

Option C. In adults, occurs more in males than in females: Incorrect. The disorder is more common in females than in males in both adults and children.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Conversion disorder, also known as dissociative neurological symptom disorder, is characterized by neurological symptoms that can't be explained by a medical condition and are believed to arise in response to psychological stressors. The symptoms do not conform with anatomical and physiological principles. The condition is more common in females in both pediatric and adult populations.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 451-467.

questions.text: A patient underwent a coronary bypass graft with the great saphenous vein. The patient now complains of paresthesia and sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be involved?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Saphenous nerve

 

  • The patient's symptoms of paresthesia and sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot indicate possible damage to the saphenous nerve, which can occur during a venous cutdown procedure to access the great saphenous vein for coronary bypass graft.
  • The saphenous nerve is a major cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve and is the longest nerve in the body.
  • After arising from the posterior division of the femoral nerve, it enters and exits the adductor canal before piercing the fascia lata between the gracilis and sartorius muscles.
  • From there, it runs along the medial border of the tibia alongside the great saphenous vein and supplies sensation to the skin over the patella, knee, leg, and foot, up to the first metatarsophalangeal joint.
  • During a venous cutdown procedure, injury to the saphenous nerve is common due to its proximity to the great saphenous vein.
  • The resulting sensory loss typically affects the medial aspect of the knee, leg, and foot.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superficial Peroneal Nerve: This nerve originates from the common peroneal nerve (a branch of the sciatic nerve). It runs in the lateral compartment of the leg.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: Supplies sensation to the dorsum (top) of the foot and a small area over the lateral aspect of the lower leg.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution and potential weakness in eversion of the foot.

 

Option C. Femoral Nerve: Arises from the lumbar plexus (L2-L4).

 

  • Motor Functions: It supplies the anterior compartment muscles of the thigh which are primarily responsible for hip flexion and knee extension.
  • Sensory Distribution: Over the anterior thigh and medial aspect of the leg (via the saphenous nerve, its branch).
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Weakness in hip flexion and knee extension along with sensory loss over its distribution.

 

Option D. Sural Nerve: This nerve is formed by branches from both the tibial and common peroneal nerves. It runs along the posterior and then lateral side of the calf.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: Supplies the posterolateral aspect of the leg and the lateral side of the foot.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: 2,00,000 IU immediately, followed by same dose after 24 hours
1,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose after 1 week
1,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose after 24 hours and after a week
2,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose 24 hours later and after 2 weeks

questions.text: What is the recommended amount of vitamin A dosage for a 2-year-old child diagnosed with keratomalacia? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 2,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose 24 hours later and after 2 weeks

 

The recommended treatment for a 2-year-old child diagnosed with keratomalacia involves high-dose vitamin A supplementation to rapidly replenish depleted stores and prevent further ocular damage. The specific dosage regimen is:

 

  1. 2,00,000 IU of vitamin A administered immediately.
  2. 2,00,000 IU administered again 24 hours later.
  3. 2,00,000 IU administered again after 2 weeks.

 

This regimen is designed to quickly correct vitamin A deficiency and provide sustained support to prevent recurrence and promote healing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The suggested vitamin A dose for a 2-year-old child diagnosed with keratomalacia is 200,000 IU, administered promptly, then repeated with the same age-appropriate amount after 24 hours and again after a span of 2 weeks.

 

Dosage of Vitamin A as per age: -

 

  • <6 months – 50,000 IU orally
  • 6-12 months – 1,00,000 IU orally
  • above 12 months – 2,00,000 IU orally
